bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 163 (Tuesday, November 3, 2015)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. GRAYSON:H.R. 3899.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, of the United States Constitution.[Page H7625]

item.title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to extend for one year the credit for residential energy efficient property.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

item.title: A bill to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide for a 5-year extension of the tax credit for residential energy efficient property.

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

summary.text: This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend through 2018 the tax credit for residential energy efficient property.

bill.title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to extend for two years the credit for residential energy efficient property.

item.title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to extend for two years the credit for residential energy efficient property.
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to extend for two years the credit for residential energy efficient property.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
